title: AIMO (Asia International Mathematical Olympiad)
description: AIMO is a highly prestigious annual math competition for students across Asia, known for its emphasis on arithmetic, algebra, and creative logic. It is interesting because it brings together thousands of top students to compete in a standardized environment that mirrors the difficulty of national Olympiads. Winning an award here provides significant leverage for students applying to elite universities in the Asia-Pacific region.
format: Preliminary Round -> National Round -> International Final (Individual and Team written rounds).
eligibility: Students aged 6-18 across participating Asian countries.
howToApply: 1. Register through a certified local or national AIMO partner. 2. Pass the preliminary round. 3. Advance to the International Finals in August.

title: WIMO (World International Mathematical Olympiad)
description: WIMO is an elite 'all-star' math Olympiad where only gold medalists from other major international competitions are invited to compete. It is prestigious because it serves as a final proving ground for the world's most talented young mathematicians, focusing on high-level number theory and geometry. The competition is designed to foster global collaboration among top-tier STEM talent.
format: One final round: 120-minute proctored written exam consisting of 30 problems.
eligibility: Gold medalists from competitions like HKIMO, TIMO, or BBB.
howToApply: 1. Achieve a gold medal in a qualifying local/international Olympiad. 2. Receive an official invitation. 3. Register for the WIMO final via the official portal.

title: Caribou Contests
description: The Caribou Math Contest is a unique, year-round international competition that features six interactive online tests per year. It is interesting for its 'Caribou Cup' ranking system and its focus on making math fun through interactive puzzles and logical challenges. It is a prestigious platform for students to maintain a high level of mathematical engagement throughout the entire academic cycle.
format: Six interactive 60-minute online contests per academic year.
eligibility: Grades K-12 globally.
howToApply: 1. Create an account on the Caribou portal. 2. Pay for a yearly pass or individual contest. 3. Participate in the scheduled monthly windows.

title: Global Mathematics Elite Competition (GMEC)
description: GMEC is a premier international math contest organized by SMO Testing to identify elite mathematical talent across borders. It is prestigious for its rigorous problem sets that challenge students on combinatorics, algebra, and advanced logic. The competition provides students with global percentile rankings that are highly valued by competitive university admissions committees.
format: Preliminary National Round -> Global Final (Written, 90 minutes).
eligibility: Primary and Secondary students globally.
howToApply: 1. Register via a national SMO Testing center. 2. Pass the qualifying national round. 3. Compete in the online Global Final in the spring.

title: NRICH Live Maths Problems
description: NRICH, a project of the University of Cambridge, offers prestigious open-ended math challenges that focus on reasoning and creative problem-solving. It is interesting because it encourages students to submit their solutions for publication on the NRICH website, providing global visibility for their mathematical thinking. Success here demonstrates a student's ability to tackle deep, non-routine theoretical problems.
format: Monthly release of open-ended problems -> Solution submission -> Public feature of best solutions.
eligibility: All ages globally (Primary and Secondary focus).
howToApply: 1. Visit the NRICH 'Live Problems' section. 2. Work on the current month's challenge. 3. Submit your reasoning and solution via the web form.

title: British Biology Olympiad (BBO)
description: The BBO is the United Kingdom's flagship biology competition for secondary students, serving as the first round of selection for the International Biology Olympiad team. It is prestigious for its association with the Royal Society of Biology and its requirement for students to apply biological principles to unfamiliar scenarios. Winning a medal here is a definitive academic honor for students aiming for medical or research careers.
format: Two 45-minute multiple-choice exams taken under proctored conditions.
eligibility: Students in UK secondary education (Year 12-13).
howToApply: 1. Schools register through the Royal Society of Biology. 2. Pay the individual entry fee. 3. Take the exam in January.

title: British Physics Olympiad (BPhO)
description: The BPhO is the premier physics competition in the UK, hosted by the University of Oxford to challenge the country's most capable young physicists. It is prestigious for its highly theoretical problems that require a deep understanding of physics intuition and mathematical rigor. Medals in the BPhO are a primary indicator for admission to elite engineering and physics programs worldwide.
format: Round 1 (Question paper) -> Round 2 (Training and selection camp).
eligibility: Students in UK secondary education (Year 13).
howToApply: 1. Register through the school's physics department. 2. Sit for the three-hour Round 1 exam. 3. Top performers are invited to Oxford for Round 2.

title: Cambridge Chemistry Challenge (C3L6)
description: The C3L6 is a prestigious chemistry competition designed by the University of Cambridge to push Year 12 students beyond their standard curriculum. It is interesting for its 'Roentgenium' award level, where top winners are invited to a residential camp at Cambridge. The problems focus on the application of chemical principles to complex, real-world research data.
format: One 90-minute written exam administered at the school.
eligibility: Students in UK Year 12 (or equivalent).
howToApply: 1. School registers via the C3L6 portal. 2. Administer the exam in June. 3. Top scorers are selected for the university training camp.

title: International Chemistry Quiz (ICQ)
description: The ICQ, organized by the Royal Australian Chemical Institute (RACI), is one of the world's largest standardized chemistry competitions. It is prestigious for its consistent global standards across over 20 participating countries, offering students a true international benchmark. The quiz focuses on chemical theory and practical laboratory concepts in a multiple-choice format.
format: One 60-minute multiple-choice exam with 30 questions.
eligibility: Secondary students globally (Grades 7-12).
howToApply: 1. Register through a national coordinator or RACI. 2. Take the exam online or in-person. 3. Receive certificates of achievement based on global percentile.

title: UK Chemistry Olympiad
description: The UK Chemistry Olympiad is the most prestigious chemistry competition for secondary students in the United Kingdom, run by the Royal Society of Chemistry. It is interesting for its incredibly difficult questions that bridge the gap between A-levels and university-level chemistry. The results are a primary factor in selecting the UK team for the international stage.
format: Round 1 (Written Exam) -> Round 2 (Residential weekend at a university) -> IChO Selection.
eligibility: Students in UK secondary education (Year 13).
howToApply: 1. Schools register via the RSC website in autumn. 2. Take the Round 1 written exam in January. 3. Top qualifiers advance to the training camp.

title: Singapore Junior Biology Olympiad (SJBO)
description: The SJBO is Singapore's premier biology competition for lower secondary students, aiming to foster early interest in life sciences. It is prestigious for its association with the Singapore Institute of Biology and its role as a developmental track for the senior national team. The competition challenges students to think critically about ecology, molecular biology, and human health.
format: One 60-minute online multiple-choice examination.
eligibility: Secondary 1-4 students in Singapore.
howToApply: 1. Register through the school's HOD of Science. 2. Pay the registration fee. 3. Complete the online exam in May.

title: Singapore Junior Physics Olympiad (SJPhO)
description: The SJPhO is a high-stakes physics competition for Singaporean secondary students that emphasizes mathematical precision and physical intuition. It is prestigious for its difficulty, serving as a key filter for the national physics training squad. The exam covers mechanics, thermodynamics, and optics at a level that challenges even the most gifted students.
format: One 90-minute multiple-choice and short-answer exam.
eligibility: Secondary 1-4 students in Singapore.
howToApply: 1. Schools register candidates via the official MOE/IPS portal. 2. Prepare for advanced physics topics beyond the O-level syllabus. 3. Sit for the exam in June.

title: Singapore Junior Chemistry Olympiad (SJChO)
description: The SJChO is an elite chemistry competition in Singapore designed to identify and nurture young chemical talent. It is prestigious for its rigorous testing of both theoretical concepts and laboratory logic, reflecting the high standards of Singapore's STEM education system. Top scorers receive medals that are highly valued for admission to competitive junior colleges.
format: One round: A two-hour written exam focusing on advanced O-level and early A-level topics.
eligibility: Secondary 1-4 students in Singapore.
howToApply: 1. Sign up through the school's science department. 2. Pay the administrative fee. 3. Attend the designated testing site in May.

title: National STEM Championship (Singapore)
description: Previously known as the National Science Challenge, this is a highly televised and prestigious STEM competition for Singaporean students. it is interesting because it requires teams to solve on-the-spot engineering and science problems under extreme pressure and scrutiny. Winners are celebrated nationally as the 'next generation' of Singapore's scientific leadership.
format: Preliminary Rounds -> Quarterfinals -> Televised Semifinals and Grand Final.
eligibility: Teams of 4 students from Singapore secondary schools.
howToApply: 1. School registers a team through the Science Centre Singapore. 2. Pass the preliminary science and engineering test. 3. Participate in the filmed challenge rounds.

title: Desafiando el Riesgo - Math Case Competition
description: Desafiando el Riesgo is a unique math-modeling competition organized by the Organization of Latino Actuaries (OLA) to promote risk management careers. It is prestigious for its focus on real-world actuarial problems and its inclusive mission to empower underrepresented students in STEM. Teams are judged on their mathematical modeling, data interpretation, and professional presentation skills.
format: Problem Set Release -> Case Analysis and Modeling -> Final Presentation.
eligibility: High school students in the U.S. and internationally.
howToApply: 1. Register your team on the OLA website. 2. Download the risk-management case study in January. 3. Submit your final report and model for judging.

title: WERC Environmental Design Contest
description: The WERC Environmental Design Contest is a prestigious engineering competition where students solve real-world environmental challenges posed by government and industry sponsors. It is interesting for its focus on sustainability and 'ready-to-implement' technological solutions. Teams are evaluated on their technical report, a working bench-scale model, and an oral presentation to industry experts.
format: Phase 1: Registration and Task Selection -> Phase 2: Technical Paper and Bench-Scale Model -> Phase 3: Final Competition in Las Cruces, NM.
eligibility: High school and Undergraduate teams; Teams of 2+.
howToApply: 1. Register your team for a specific environmental task. 2. Develop a bench-scale solution. 3. Submit your report and prepare for the final event.

title: NASA RASC-AL Competition
description: RASC-AL is one of NASA's most prestigious collegiate-level competitions that occasionally opens categories for elite high school engineering teams. it is interesting for its focus on revolutionary aerospace concepts, such as lunar bases or Mars transit vehicles. Winning teams present their work to NASA engineers and often receive funding to further develop their aerospace prototypes.
format: Proposal Submission -> Selection of Finalist Teams -> Final Competition and Presentation at NASA.
eligibility: Undergraduate and high-reaching High School teams.
howToApply: 1. Choose one of the NASA-specified mission themes. 2. Submit a detailed technical proposal by the March deadline. 3. If selected, develop a full technical paper and presentation.

title: Aerial Drone Competition
description: The Aerial Drone Competition, organized by RECF, is a fast-paced STEM challenge where students fly drones and program autonomous flight paths. It is prestigious for its focus on the burgeoning field of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and its requirement for both piloting skill and coding precision. Teams compete in high-energy matches that simulate real-world drone applications.
format: Pilot Skills Matches -> Autonomous Flight Challenges -> Teamwork Tournament.
eligibility: Middle and High School students; Teams of 2+.
howToApply: 1. Register your team via the RobotEvents portal. 2. Practice both manual piloting and block/Python coding. 3. Attend local and regional qualifiers in the spring.

title: Discovery 3M Young Scientist Challenge
description: The 3M Young Scientist Challenge is the nation's premier middle school science competition, focusing on innovation and communication. It is prestigious for its mentorship program, where finalists work directly with 3M scientists to turn their ideas into prototypes. Winning the title of 'America's Top Young Scientist' often results in national media coverage and significant cash awards.
format: 1-2 minute video submission (Problem/Solution) -> Selection of Top 10 Finalists -> Mentorship and Summer Prototype.
eligibility: Grades 5-8 in the United States.
howToApply: 1. Identify a problem in your community or the world. 2. Record a video explaining your original scientific solution. 3. Submit the entry by the May deadline.

title: Yale Young Global Scholars (YYGS) 2026
description: YYGS is an elite academic leadership program at Yale University that brings together the world's most talented high schoolers for two weeks of intensive STEM study. It is prestigious for its competitive application process and its focus on solving global challenges through interdisciplinary science. Students gain access to Yale's world-class labs and faculty while building a global network of peers.
format: Application Review -> Acceptance -> Two-week residential session on Yale's campus.
eligibility: High school students (Grade 10 or 11) globally.
howToApply: 1. Complete the comprehensive Yale application. 2. Submit transcripts and a teacher recommendation by Jan 7. 3. Participate in the summer session if accepted.

title: USNCO Local Exam (Southern Arizona Section)
description: The Southern Arizona local section of the Chemistry Olympiad is a critical qualifier for students aiming for the national chemistry team. It is prestigious for its rigorous testing environment and its partnership with the University of Arizona. Top performers receive medals and the opportunity to compete in the high-stakes national three-part exam.
format: One 110-minute written examination (60 multiple-choice questions).
eligibility: High school students in the Southern Arizona ACS region.
howToApply: 1. Parent or guardian registers the student on the ACS portal. 2. Coordinate with local coordinator Dr. Suchi Perera. 3. Take the exam in early March.

title: Harker Math Invitational
description: The Harker Math Invitational is a prestigious middle school math tournament held at the Harker School in Silicon Valley. it is interesting for its high concentration of top-tier mathematical talent from across the Bay Area's elite private and public schools. The problems are designed to challenge logic and speed, mirroring the difficulty of national competitions like MathCounts.
format: Individual Round -> Team Round -> Countdown Round (Top scorers buzzer match).
eligibility: Middle school students (Grades 6-8).
howToApply: 1. School or coach registers teams via the Harker portal. 2. Pay the tournament registration fee. 3. Attend the competition day in San Jose in March.

title: TKA Math Tournament
description: Held at The King's Academy in Sunnyvale, this tournament is a major regional hub for middle school math in California. It is prestigious for its early-season timing, allowing students to test their skills before the official MathCounts chapter competitions. It features a high-intensity individual round and a collaborative team challenge.
format: Individual Exam -> Team Round -> Awards Ceremony.
eligibility: Middle school students (Grades 6-8) in California.
howToApply: 1. Register your school's team through the TKA math portal. 2. Coordinate student rosters and payment by January. 3. Compete in person in Sunnyvale.

title: CyberPatriot (National Youth Cyber Defense)
description: CyberPatriot is the premier national high school cybersecurity competition, created by the Air Force Association to inspire students toward STEM careers. It is prestigious for its 'National Finals' in Maryland and its use of professional-grade virtual machine software. Teams must defend a virtual network from cyber threats, demonstrating skills in OS hardening and network security.
format: Qualifying Rounds -> State Rounds -> Regional Semifinals -> National Finals.
eligibility: Middle and High School students; Teams of 2-6.
howToApply: 1. Register your team via the Air Force Association portal. 2. Set up virtual machines provided by the competition. 3. Compete in scheduled online defensive rounds throughout the winter.

title: American Computer Science League (ACSL)
description: ACSL is one of the world's most prestigious computer science competitions for K-12 students, focusing on both coding and theoretical concepts. It is interesting because it tests students on topics like Boolean algebra, bit-string flicking, and graph theory—concepts typically reserved for college courses. Success in ACSL is a high-value signal for students applying to elite computer science programs.
format: Four online contest rounds (Short Answer + Programming) -> Invitational Finals.
eligibility: Elementary, Middle, and High School students globally.
howToApply: 1. School registers with ACSL. 2. Students complete four individual contests throughout the year. 3. Top scorers are invited to the global Finals in May.

title: International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) Finals
description: The IMO is the 'world championship' of high school mathematics, bringing together the absolute top talent from over 100 countries. It is exceptionally prestigious, as each country sends only its six best mathematicians to solve six incredibly difficult proof-based problems. A gold medal at the IMO is one of the highest individual intellectual honors in the world.
format: Two days of testing; 4.5 hours per day; 3 proof-based problems per day.
eligibility: National teams of six students; Selection via national Olympiads.
howToApply: 1. Win at the highest national level (e.g., USAMO in the USA). 2. Attend the national training camp. 3. Earn selection for the official six-person national team.

title: International Physics Olympiad (IPhO) Finals
description: The 2026 IPhO in Colombia represents the pinnacle of high school physics achievement on a global stage. It is prestigious for its intense theoretical and experimental exams that challenge students on classical mechanics, relativity, and quantum physics. Competing at IPhO identifies a student as one of the world's elite scientific minds, often opening doors to top research institutions.
format: Theoretical Exam (5 hours) + Experimental Lab Exam (5 hours).
eligibility: National teams of five students; Selection via national physics Olympiads.
howToApply: 1. Qualify through the national selection process (e.g., U.S. Physics Team). 2. Attend the national team training camp. 3. Travel to Colombia for the International Finals.

title: International Chemistry Olympiad (IChO) Finals
description: The IChO in Uzbekistan is the world championship for high school chemists, bringing together national delegations from over 80 countries. It is prestigious for its rigorous focus on analytical, organic, and physical chemistry through both theory and advanced laboratory practicals. Winning an IChO medal is a globally recognized mark of academic excellence in the chemical sciences.
format: Theoretical Exam (5 hours) + Practical Laboratory Exam (5 hours).
eligibility: National teams of four students; Selection via national chemistry Olympiads.
howToApply: 1. Place in the top tier of the national exam (e.g., USNCO). 2. Be selected for the national study camp. 3. Represent your country in Uzbekistan.

title: International Olympiad in Informatics (IOI) Finals
description: The IOI is the premier global competition for high school programmers, focusing on algorithmic problem solving and optimization. It is prestigious for its extreme difficulty, as students must design and implement complex algorithms in C++ to solve novel problems. The 2026 Finals in Uzbekistan identify the most capable future software engineers and researchers in the world.
format: Two days of testing; 5 hours per day; 3 algorithmic problems per day.
eligibility: National teams of four students; Selection via national informatics Olympiads.
howToApply: 1. Qualify through the national selection (e.g., USACO in the USA). 2. Place in the top four at the national team selection camp. 3. Compete in Uzbekistan.

title: International Geography Olympiad (iGeo) Finals
description: The 2026 iGeo in Thailand is the leading global competition for geography students, emphasizing spatial analysis and environmental sustainability. It is prestigious for its multi-format testing, which includes a fieldwork exercise where students must gather and analyze data in a real-world setting. Medals at iGeo demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of the world's physical and human systems.
format: Written Response Test + Multimedia Test + Fieldwork Mapping Exercise.
eligibility: National teams of four students; Selection via national geography championships.
howToApply: 1. Qualify through the national selection round (e.g., IAC in the US). 2. Be selected for the four-person national team. 3. Compete in Thailand.

title: MathCounts Indiana State Competition
description: The Indiana State MathCounts competition is a high-stakes event that gathers the best middle school math talent from across the state's regional chapters. It is prestigious for being the primary gateway to the National MathCounts competition, with only the top four individual scorers earning a spot on the state team. The final 'Countdown Round' buzzer match is a major highlight of the event.
format: Sprint Round -> Target Round -> Team Round -> Countdown Round.
eligibility: Top middle schoolers qualifying from Indiana chapter competitions.
howToApply: 1. Place in the top tier at an Indiana local chapter competition in February. 2. Receive invitation for the state event. 3. Compete in Indianapolis in March.

title: MathCounts Texas State Competition
description: The Texas State MathCounts competition is widely regarded as one of the most difficult and prestigious state math tournaments in the country. Given the state's massive population and high density of math talent, winning a spot on the four-person Texas national team is a significant national achievement. The event is a high-energy showcase of the state's brightest young problem solvers.
format: Sprint Round -> Target Round -> Team Round -> Countdown Round.
eligibility: Top middle schoolers from Texas regional chapters.
howToApply: 1. Win at a Texas regional chapter competition (e.g., Houston or Austin). 2. Submit state registration forms. 3. Compete at the state finals in March.

title: MathCounts Ohio State Competition
description: The Ohio State MathCounts competition brings together the top middle school math students from the state's regional districts for a day of rigorous problem solving. It is prestigious for its long-standing history and its role in selecting the Ohio team for the National RTX competition in Orlando. The competition fosters a strong community among the state's STEM-focused educators and students.
format: Sprint Round -> Target Round -> Team Round -> Countdown Round.
eligibility: Top middle school qualifiers from Ohio regional chapters.
howToApply: 1. Qualify through a local Ohio chapter competition in February. 2. Receive advancement notification. 3. Attend the state finals in Columbus.

title: MathCounts Alaska State Competition
description: The Alaska State MathCounts competition is the premier middle school math event for the state, drawing talent from remote and metropolitan districts alike. It is prestigious for its role in identifying the top four students who will represent Alaska on the national stage in Florida. The event provides a unique forum for the state's young mathematical minds to connect and compete.
format: Sprint Round -> Target Round -> Team Round -> Countdown Round.
eligibility: Middle school students qualifying from Alaska chapter events.
howToApply: 1. Compete in a local Alaska chapter competition in early February. 2. Qualify as a top individual or team member. 3. Travel to the state finals on March 21.

title: Florida MATHCOUNTS State Competition
description: The Florida State MathCounts competition, held at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, is a high-prestige event that determines the state's delegation for the national finals. It is interesting for its high energy and its association with a leading aerospace institution, providing students with a unique look at engineering applications of math. The buzzer-based Countdown Round is particularly intense and spectator-friendly.
format: Sprint Round -> Target Round -> Team Round -> Countdown Round.
eligibility: Top middle schoolers from Florida's regional chapters.
howToApply: 1. Place as a top scorer in a Florida local chapter competition. 2. Register for the state event in Daytona Beach. 3. Compete in person on March 20.

title: AIMO National Round (USA/Canada)
description: The National Round of the Asia International Mathematical Olympiad in North America is a prestigious online event for students aiming for international honors. it is interesting because it uses the same standardized Asian-centric problem sets, allowing Western students to benchmark themselves against the high standards of math education in the East. Top scorers are invited to the global gala in August.
format: 90-minute online written exam focusing on arithmetic and geometry.
eligibility: Students who passed the AIMO preliminary round.
howToApply: 1. Pass the AIMO preliminary round in the winter. 2. Pay the national round registration fee. 3. Take the proctored online exam in March.

title: Science Olympiad Regional (General)
description: Science Olympiad Regionals are the foundational entry points for the nation's most popular team-based STEM competition. They are prestigious for their wide range of events—spanning from forensics to structural engineering—and their role in filtering teams for the state championships. Succeeding at the regional level requires months of preparation across a 15-person team, demonstrating exceptional breadth of scientific knowledge.
format: Multi-event day featuring 23 distinct 'study,' 'build,' and 'lab' events.
eligibility: Middle and High School students; Teams of 15.
howToApply: 1. School registers with the national Science Olympiad office. 2. Form a team and assign events to members. 3. Compete at a local university-hosted regional tournament.

title: Science Olympiad State Tournament
description: The Science Olympiad State Tournament is a high-stakes championship that gathers the elite regional winners to compete for a single spot at the National Tournament. It is prestigious for its intense competition and the high level of technical mastery required in the 'build' events like Bridge and Flight. Winning at state is a major institutional achievement for any participating school.
format: A full day of 23 competitive science and engineering events.
eligibility: Top 1-2 teams qualifying from each regional tournament.
howToApply: 1. Win the top placement at a local regional SciOly tournament. 2. Complete state registration and roster verification. 3. Compete at the state university host site in March or April.

title: PhysicsBowl 2026 (Global Results)
description: The release of the global PhysicsBowl results is a major date for students waiting to see their standing among over 10,000 international participants. it is prestigious because top-ranked students (Top 100 globally or Top 10 regionally) are awarded prestigious certificates and recognition from the AAPT. These results are highly influential in demonstrating academic excellence to top-tier STEM universities.
format: Ranked list based on the March 45-minute examination.
eligibility: Students who sat for the PhysicsBowl exam in March.
howToApply: 1. Complete the exam through your school in March. 2. Await the digital score release in late April. 3. Check for inclusion on the Global Top 100 list.

title: Purple Comet! 2026 (Competition Window)
description: The Purple Comet! Math Meet competition window is a ten-day period during which international teams can log in to solve as many problems as possible. it is prestigious for its 'integer answer' format and its emphasis on collaborative problem solving in a free, global environment. The window's flexibility allows students from over 60 countries to participate during their local school hours.
format: Ten-day window for a single 60-90 minute team session.
eligibility: Middle and High school teams of 1-6 students.
howToApply: 1. Ensure your teacher has registered a team by the start of the window. 2. Log in between April 14 and April 23. 3. Submit your team's solutions for as many of the 30 problems as possible.

title: Math Kangaroo 2026 (Competition Day)
description: Math Kangaroo Day is the simultaneous global administration of the world's most widespread math contest. it is prestigious for its unique focus on making math accessible and fun while still identifying the top 1% of logical thinkers globally. On this day, over 6 million students solve visual and reasoning-based puzzles that celebrate the joy of mathematics.
format: One round: 75-minute multiple-choice exam.
eligibility: Grades 1-12 globally.
howToApply: 1. Register online or via your school by the February deadline. 2. Report to your assigned in-person center or log in online. 3. Complete the exam on Thursday, March 19.

title: ARML 2026 (Competition Weekend)
description: ARML Weekend is the definitive 'Big Ten' style gathering of the nation's best high school math teams at four regional sites. it is prestigious for its high-energy Relay and Guts rounds and the presence of elite college recruiters. The weekend is a celebration of mathematical community, bringing together 15-student regional teams to vie for the national title.
format: Two days of team, power, individual, and relay rounds.
eligibility: 15-student regional math teams.
howToApply: 1. Qualify for your local regional team (e.g., Texas, NYC, SFBA) in the spring. 2. Travel to one of the four host university sites (Penn State, UNLV, Iowa, or Georgia). 3. Compete in the national rounds on May 30.

title: USABO Semifinal (National Result Release)
description: The release of the USABO Semifinal results is a pivotal moment that identifies the 20 finalists for the U.S. Biology Olympiad. it is prestigious because these students are recognized as the top twenty biological minds in the nation's high schools. Being a 'Top 20 Finalist' is a transformative accolade that frequently secures student placements at the world's most elite research universities.
format: National ranking release following the March proctored exam.
eligibility: Students who sat for the USABO Semifinal Exam.
howToApply: 1. Complete the Semifinal exam in early March. 2. Await the result notification from CEE in April. 3. If selected for the Top 20, finalize travel for the National Finals.

title: MathCounts National RTX Finals
description: The RTX MATHCOUNTS National Competition is the ultimate destination for the nation's best middle school math students, held in Orlando, Florida. it is prestigious for its televised 'Countdown Round' and its role as the definitive national middle school math championship. Only the top four students from each state earn a trip to compete for the national individual and team titles.
format: Written Exam -> Team Round -> Televised Countdown Round (Top 12 individual buzzer match).
eligibility: Top 4 individuals and 1 coach from each state/territory.
howToApply: 1. Win a spot on your state's four-person national team in March. 2. Receive an official invitation and travel package. 3. Compete in Orlando in May.

title: Maryland MATHCOUNTS Chapter (Annapolis)
description: The Annapolis Chapter competition is a major regional event in the Maryland MathCounts circuit, often drawing students from the capital's high-performing schools. it is prestigious for its high level of competition and its location in the state capital, serving as the first step toward the state championship in Baltimore. The winners here are recognized as the top middle school math talent in the region.
format: Sprint Round -> Target Round -> Team Round -> Countdown Round.
eligibility: Middle school students in the Annapolis regional district.
howToApply: 1. Register your school's team through the Maryland MathCounts portal. 2. Attend the competition on Saturday, February 28. 3. Place in the top tier to advance to the state finals.

title: MathCounts Ohio (Akron District)
description: The Akron District Chapter competition is a key regional hub for math talent in Northeastern Ohio. it is prestigious for its history of producing state-level champions and its role in bringing together the region's best young problem solvers. The event emphasizes both individual speed and team-based collaboration in a high-stakes competitive environment.
format: Sprint Round -> Target Round -> Team Round -> Countdown Round.
eligibility: Middle school students in the Akron/Northeastern Ohio district.
howToApply: 1. School registers with the Ohio Society of Professional Engineers. 2. Participate in the Akron district tournament on February 7. 3. Advance to the Ohio state finals based on placement.

title: MathCounts Texas (Abilene Chapter)
description: The Abilene Chapter competition serves as the primary gateway for middle school math talent in West Texas. it is prestigious for its role in identifying the region's top students for the highly competitive Texas state championship. The event fosters a culture of mathematical excellence in the local school districts and celebrates student achievement in STEM.
format: Sprint Round -> Target Round -> Team Round -> Countdown Round.
eligibility: Middle school students in the Abilene/West Texas district.
howToApply: 1. Register through a local Texas MathCounts school coordinator. 2. Compete in the Abilene chapter tournament on February 7. 3. Qualify for the Texas state finals in March.

title: MathCounts Indiana (AA Potter)
description: The AA Potter Chapter competition is a prestigious regional event in the Indiana MathCounts series, held in the West Lafayette area. it is interesting for its proximity to Purdue University, often attracting children of elite STEM faculty and researchers. Winners here advance to the state finals with a strong reputation for high performance.
format: Sprint Round -> Target Round -> Team Round -> Countdown Round.
eligibility: Middle school students in the West Lafayette/AA Potter district.
howToApply: 1. Ensure school registration via the Indiana MathCounts portal. 2. Attend the chapter competition on Valentine's Day. 3. Secure a top-four individual spot to advance to state.

title: Illinois JSHS (Symposium Day)
description: The Symposium Day for the Illinois Junior Science and Humanities Symposium at SIU is the culmination of the state's most prestigious oral research competition. it is prestigious for its professional academic setting where students present their original work to panels of university judges. The top finalists selected on this day earn thousands of dollars in scholarships and a trip to the National JSHS.
format: Final Oral Presentations (12 min) + Professional Q&A Session (6 min).
eligibility: Students whose research papers were selected in the January round.
howToApply: 1. Submit a top-tier research paper by the January 21 deadline. 2. Be selected as one of the regional finalists. 3. Present your research in person at SIU on February 21.

title: USA Astronomy Olympiad (NAC Result)
description: The release of the National Astronomy Competition results is the final step in determining the 2026 U.S. Astronomy Team. it is prestigious as it recognizes the five students who will represent the United States at the International Olympiad on Astronomy and Astrophysics (IOAA). Medalists in this round are considered the top pre-collegiate astronomers in the country.
format: Score release and team selection announcement following the April exam.
eligibility: Students who sat for the National Astronomy Competition (NAC).
howToApply: 1. Complete the NAC proctored exam in April. 2. Await the team selection announcement from USAAAO in May. 3. If selected, begin intensive training for the International IOAA.
